case_name: Union of India and the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner, Maharashtra State v. the respondent company

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2591 of 1966 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated September 17, 1965 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 380 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2591 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment award order dated September 17, 1965 the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 380 of 1964.

facts.text: The appellants are the Union of India and the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner, Maharashtra State.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal on certificate, by the Union of India and the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner., Maharashtra State, is directed against the judgment and order dated September 17, 1965 of the Bombay High Court

facts.text: The respondent is a limited company having its Head Office at Ogalawadi in Satara District manufacturing Glassware, Stoves, Lanterns and Enamel wares.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent a limited companypany having its Head Office at Ogalawadi in Satara District was manufacturing at the relevant time Glassware, Stoves, Lanterns and Enamel wares.

facts.text: The respondent company had sections: Glass Manufacturing Section, Lantern and Safety Stoves Section, Enamel Section, General Section and Canteen Section.

anchor.surface_text: It had several sections in its factory, namely,  1  Glass Manufacturing Section,  2  Lantern and Safety Stoves Section,  3  Enamel Section,  4  General Section and  5  Canteen Section.

facts.text: The Employees Provident Fund Act, 1952 came into force on November 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On November 1, 1952, The Employees Provident Fund Act, 1952, Act No. XIX of 1952  hereinafter to be referred to as the Act , came into force

facts.text: There is no controversy that the Act was made applicable to the respondent on October 6, 1952 and the Company had been paying contributions from November 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbercontroversy that the Act was made applicable to the respondent on October 6, 1952 and the Company had been paying its companytribution to the Employees Provident Fund from November 1, 1952.

facts.text: According to the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner, the Act and Scheme applied to the entire body of employees working under the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner, the Act and the Scheme framed thereunder applied to the entire body of employees working under the respondent.

facts.text: The company raised objections that only employees in Lantern and Stoves Section were covered but continued to make contributions for other employees.

anchor.surface_text: Though the Company then raised objections on the ground that only the employees in the Lantern and Stoves Section were companyered by the Scheme and that it was bound to make companytributions only in respect of those employees, nevertheless, the Company companytinued to make its share of companytribution to the Provident Fund even in respect of other employees working in other sections.

facts.text: Bombay High Court in Nagpur Glass Works Ltd. v. RPFC on March 7, 1957 upheld that Act applies only to sections covered by Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: a Division Bench of the, Bombay High Court, by its decision dated March 7, 1957 reported in The Nagpur Glass Works Ltd., v. Regional Provident Fund Commis- sioner 1  upheld the companytentions of the Nagpur Glass Works that the Act and the Scheme applied only to such sections or departments of the Company as were companyered by Schedule

facts.text: Supreme Court reversed Bombay HC on March 14, 1962 in RPFC Bombay v. Shree Krishna Metal Mfg Co., holding Act applies to composite factories.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Bombay High Court was reversed by this Court on March 14, 1962 in the decision reported in The Regional Provident Fund Commissioner, Bombay v. Shree Krishna Metal Manufacturing Co., Bhandara 2 . This Court after referring to the relevant Provisions of the Act including s. 2A which had been introduced by an amendment in 1960 held that the Act applied to companyposite factories

facts.text: After Bombay HC decision, respondent discontinued contributions for employees other than Lantern and Stoves Section.

anchor.surface_text: To resume the narrative, after the decision of the Bombay High Court, the respondent began to discontinue making companytributions in respect of the employees, other than those working in the Lantern and Stoves Section.

facts.text: Employees raised dispute on discontinuance, State Govt referred to Industrial Tribunal Maharashtra as Reference No. I.D. 29 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The employees raised a dispute regarding the discontinuance of the Provident Fund Scheme and in companysequence the State Government referred the dispute to the Industrial Tribunal, Maharashtra, being Reference No. I.D. 29 of 1960.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal award dated June 24, 1960 directed contributions at 8-1/3% for certain years and 6-1/4% from March 1, 1960, none for loss years.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal, by its award dated June 24, 1960, after companysidering the financial position of the Company, held that for the years, 1951, 1957, 1958 and 1959, the Company should make companytributions to the Provident fund at the rate of 8- 1/3 per cent of the basic wages to the workers uncovered by the Scheme under the Act and that the Company need number make any companytributions for the years 1950 and 1952 to 1956, as during those years they have suffered loses. It gave a further direction that from March 1, 1960 the Company is to make companytribution at 6-1/4 per cent of the wages and Dearness Allowance.

facts.text: RPFC issued notice of demand dated May 22, 1963 for contributions from November 1, 1952 to December 31, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: quashing the numberice of demand dated May 22, 1963 issued by the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner.

facts.text: Bombay High Court quashed the demand notice dated May 22, 1963 holding there was a final decision under s.19A by Central Govt that Act applies only to certain sections.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, by its judgment and order under appeal, has held that the letter dated August 19, 1959 sent by the Central Provident Fund Commissioner, New Delhi, to the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner read with the letter dated September 21, 1959 sent by the latter to the respondent clearly shows that there has been a decision under s. 19A of the Act

facts.text: Supreme Court held no decision under s.19A was taken; actions were provisional pending SC appeal on Bombay HC judgment.

anchor.surface_text: From the entire companyres- pondence it is clear that there has been numberfinal decision taken by the Central Government under S. 1.9A of the Act regarding number-applicability of the Act and the Scheme in respect of the, three sections of the respondents establishment.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the Act and Scheme apply to all sections of the respondent's composite establishment.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court rejecting the companytentions of the respondent in this regard and holding that the manufacture of glass material, enamel and lantern and stoves, was the industrial activity of the respondent and that the decision of this Court squarely applies which, in companysequence, makes the Act and the Scheme applicable to all sections of the respondent.

facts.text: Central PF Commissioner letter dated August 19, 1959 advised that enamel, lanterns and stoves sections covered, refund others.

anchor.surface_text: The Central Provident Fund Commissioner in this letter states We have since been advised by the Government of India that the enamel and lanterns and stoves sections of the Ogale Glass Works Ltd., will companytinue to be companyered under the Employees Provident Fund Act, 1952. The Provident Fund companytributions deposited by the management in respect of the remaining sections of the factory viz.,  i  general, glass, and  iii  canteen may be refunded to them.

facts.text: RPFC letter dated September 21, 1959 to respondent stated Act applies to Enamel, Lantern and Stoves sections, refund others.

anchor.surface_text: The second letter dated September 21, 1 959 was addressed to ,the respondent by the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner after getting clarification from the Central Provident Fund Commissioner. In this letter it is stated that the Act and the Scame framed thereunder has been made applicable to Enamel and Latern and Stoves sections of the respondents factory and that the amounts deposited by them in respect of the other sections

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal award does not bar statutory liability under the Act as appellants not parties to it.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly the appellants were number parties to the award. No doubt under the Industrial Disputes Act the award will be binding as against the respondent and its workmen. But the appellants are seeking in these proceedings to enforce the statutory duty cast upon them

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court judgment and dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the judgment and order of the High Court dated September 17, 1965 are set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent will stand dismissed. The appeal is allowed and the appellants will be entitled to their companyts in this appeal.

facts.text: Company introduced Provident Fund Scheme in 1946 paying 12 pies in a rupee as employer's contribution.

anchor.surface_text: In or about 1946 the Company had introduced a Provident Fund Scheme for its workers under which it paid 12 pies in a rupee as the employers companytribution towards the said fund.

facts.text: In 1951 Provident Fund Scheme amended to make contributions only if profits.

anchor.surface_text: In 1951 the Provident Fund Scheme was amended and the Company agreed to make companytributions to the. fund only if it made profits.

holdings.text: The Act and the Scheme apply to all sections of the respondent's composite establishment.

anchor.surface_text: We can straightaway dispose of the last point urged by Mr. Tarkunde that the Act does not apply to all sections of the respondents establishment. We have already referred to the decision of the High Court rejecting the contentions of the respondent in this regard and holding that the manufacture of glass material, enamel and lantern and stoves, was the industrial activity of the respondent and that the decision of this Court squarely applies which, in consequence, makes the Act and the Scheme applicable to all sections of the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedent in Regional Provident Fund Commissioner v. Shree Krishna Metal Mfg Co. that Act applies to composite factories even pre-s.2A amendment; High Court correctly applied facts to precedent.

holdings.text: There has been no final decision taken by the Central Government under s.19A of the Act regarding non-applicability of the Act and the Scheme to certain sections.

anchor.surface_text: From the entire correspondence it is clear that there has been no final decision taken by the Central Government under S. 19A of the Act regarding non-applicability of the Act and the Scheme in respect of the, three sections of the respondents establishment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entire correspondence shows letters dated Aug 19, 1959 and Sep 21, 1959 were provisional/tentative pending Supreme Court appeal against Bombay HC judgment; no difficulty arose post-judicial interpretation warranting s.19A.

holdings.text: There was no occasion for the Central Government to give a direction under s.19A after the Bombay High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Now the question arises whether there was any occasion for the Central Government to give a direction under s. 19A in the, case of the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-judicial decision interpreting Act (Bombay HC), no doubt/difficulty arises for s.19A; authorities bound by court judgment until reversed.

holdings.text: The award of the Industrial Tribunal in I.T. No.29 of 1960 does not bind the appellants or bar enforcement of statutory liability under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly the appellants were not parties to the award. No doubt under the Industrial Disputes Act the award will be binding as against the respondent and its workmen. But the appellants are seeking in these proceedings to enforce the statutory duty cast upon them

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants not parties to award; award binds only employer/workmen under Industrial Disputes Act; appellants enforce independent statutory duty under EPF Act.

holdings.text: The respondent is liable to pay administrative charges along with provident fund contributions.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability for contributions under Act implies liability for associated administrative charges.

holdings.text: The judgment of the Bombay High Court dated September 17, 1965 is set aside and the writ petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the judgment and order of the High Court dated September 17, 1965 are set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent will stand dismissed. The appeal is allowed and the appellants will be entitled to their costs in this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of holdings on s.19A, applicability, and award; appellants entitled to enforce demand notice.

holdings.text: Even if a decision under s.19A was taken, it was not inconsistent with the Act.

anchor.surface_text: From the discussion contained above, it is also clear that even if a decision has been taken by the Central Government, it is not inconsistent with the provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisional decision conformed to then-binding Bombay HC judgment; obiter as primary holding is no s.19A decision.

Shree Krishna Metal Manufacturing Co., Bhandara 2 . This Court after referring to the relevant Provisions of the Act including s. 2A which had been introduced by an amendment in 1960 held that the Act applied to companyposite factories

precedents.case_name: Regional Provident Fund Commissioner Bombay v Shree Krishna Metal Manufacturing Co Bhandara
precedents.cited_proposition: the Act applied to composite factories and that the Glass Works therein was commercially engaged in a Scheduled industry among others and hence the Act was applicable to it. All the employees working under the said Glass Works were covered by the Act and the Scheme
precedents.cited_holding: Act applies to composite factories with scheduled and non-scheduled industries; all employees covered

anchor.surface_text: 2  1962 Supp. 3 S. C. R. 815, 5 28 Works therein was companymercially engaged in a Scheduled industry among others and hence the Act was applicable to it. On this basis, this Court held that all the employees working under the said Glass Works were companyered by the Act and the Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: We can straightaway dispose of the last point urged by Mr. Tarkunde that the Act does not apply to all sections of the respondents establishment. We have already referred to the decision of the High Court rejecting the contentions of the respondent in this regard and holding that the manufacture of glass material, enamel and lantern and stoves, was the industrial activity of the respondent and that the decision of this Court squarely applies which, in consequence, makes the Act and the Scheme applicable to all sections of the respondent.

In the result, the judgment and order of the High Court dated September 17, 1965 are set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent will stand dismissed. The appeal is allowed and the appellants will be entitled to their costs in this appeal.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 that no final decision was taken supports the concept c5 that High Court erred in holding letters constitute final decision

anchor.surface_text: From the entire correspondence it is clear that there has been no final decision taken by the Central Government under S. 19A of the Act regarding non-applicability of the Act and the Scheme in respect of the, three sections of the respondents establishment.

In the result, the judgment and order of the High Court dated September 17, 1965 are set aside and the writ petition filed by the respondent will stand dismissed. The appeal is allowed and the appellants will be entitled to their costs in this appeal.
